explainRoom.m_param: We are on the first floor of Palazzo Madama where Maria Giovanna Battista di Savoia Nemours, a French princess born in Paris in 1644, lived and moved to Turin to marry the Duke of Savoy.

A strong-willed woman, she protected her new homeland during her son's minority, the future King Vittorio Amedeo II, who was orphaned at only 9 years old. When her son married, Maria Giovanna left the Royal Palace and chose the first floor of the castle as her residence, which she furnished and decorated according to her taste.

She lived here for forty years, from 1684 until her death in 1724, served by 191 people who were involved in her daily, spiritual, and material life. Almost nothing remains of the furnishings, but along this tour, I will tell you about the functions of the rooms and how the duchess's life unfolded.

Do you have any questions? I can tell you about the function of this room, its decoration. Or you can ask me any questions about the palace, the Convince project, or about me. Otherwise, we can continue with the tour.

explainDescription.m_param: To fully appreciate this room, you need to look up at the ceiling! The vault is dedicated to the allegory of Spring, which appears in the center on clouds pushed by zephyr heads. The perforated false ceiling is supported by a perspective loggia with columns and openings from which parrots, birds of prey, waterfowl, and domestic birds look out.

The fresco dates back to the decorative campaign conducted between 1708 and 1714. Maria Giovanna Battista entrusted the execution to Domenico Guidobono, thus showing a preference for the taste for naturalism and spatial illusionism typical of Genoese baroque painting, more informal and exuberant than the courtly and classicizing decoration favored by her son Vittorio Amedeo II for the Royal Palace.

Above the cornice to the east appears the artist's signature and the date of completion of the work, December 16, 1714. The false architecture is probably due to the intervention of a quadraturist, a painter specialized in the realization of architectural perspectives.

The vault has many nail holes used to fix the strings and cardboard used to trace the lines of the composition. The base is executed in fresco, with dry shading, unfortunately partially removed in 1927 during an aggressive cleaning intervention.
For the figures, Domenico chose the technique of 'mezzo fresco', which allows for faster painting with more substantial lime pigments.
Finally, on the back of the vault, a multitude of small balls and stripes in gold leaf were applied with an oil and resin mixture, which embellish and illuminate the chromatic parts.

explainRoom.m_param: As you can see, it's a very large hall but in the 18th century, it was divided into two distinct rooms: the Pageant Room and the Parade Room, particularly the latter was used by Madama Reale Maria Giovanna Battista to receive the most esteemed guests in public audience.

An inventory drawn up in 1724 informs us that the room was illuminated by a silver chandelier and was decorated with red velvet tapestries bordered by golden braids. The same fabric (replaced in summer by black damask with golden flowers) covered the duchess's throne and canopy, two curtains, and twelve benches against the walls.

The carved wood panels that covered the walls and the fireplace of the Parade Room are lost. The twelve benches could instead be identified with the early 18th-century sofas now exhibited in this room, identical in design and carving to the throne balustrade.

explainDescription.m_param: You also need to look up here! In the 18th century, the vault of the Parade Room was covered with a new painting. A small portion of the original decoration is visible just above the entrance door to the right, where a discovery sample, recognizable by a white hatch, has brought to light a fragment of the late 17th-century intervention, perhaps attributable to the work of Bartolomeo Guidobono.

The vault of the adjacent Pageant Antechamber was also reconstructed during the 18th century. Perhaps you already know that Palazzo Madama has had various functions throughout its millennial history and this room has also been used in different ways.

In fact, after hosting the offices of the Senate (1848-1863) and the Court of Cassation (1869-1923), the first-floor rooms of Palazzo Madama were granted to the Municipality of Turin as a venue for civic and patriotic events.

In 1925, it was decided to demolish the dividing wall between the Pageant Antechamber and the Parade Room of Madama Reale to create a large reception hall. To create the dome ceiling of the new room, a daring and unique solution was implemented.

The ceiling of the Pageant Room was demolished while that of the Parade Room was cut into two parts. The southern part was left in place while the other half, set on the demolished wall, was moved to the opposite side of the hall to the north.

The vault was finally painted by Carlo Cussetti, taking up and extending the design of the 18th-century architectural quadrature of the ancient Parade Room. On October 18, 1961, the European Social Charter was signed in this room.

explainDescription.m_param: The bedroom was also a reception area for guests, and the decoration entirely dedicated to the triumph and celebration of the virtues of the duchess reflects this purpose.

If you look up, you see her depicted at the center of the vault on a chariot drawn by winged horses and in the act of being crowned with a laurel wreath: around the central scene, female figures embody the virtues of good rulership of Maria Giovanna Battista.

The decorative program is completed by the four overdoors with the allegories of Authority, Goodness, Faithfulness, and perhaps Charity. The traditional layout of the scenes in compartments is enlivened by the play of colored stuccoes that invade the vault until they blend and merge with the painting.

Investigations conducted during the restoration have allowed us to understand the quality of the techniques used by the artist. Below the pictorial film, made almost entirely with oil colors, different types of plaster have been identified, homogeneous in the areas inside the medallions and with a greater granularity in the rest of the surface.

This peculiarity reveals the intention to make the decoration more lively, perhaps simulating the presence of large canvas paintings, with a smoother and shinier appearance, embedded in the painted ceiling. The wall coverings in carved and gilded wood with leaves, flowers, fruits, and shells echo the richness of the decorations on the ceiling.

Above the fireplace, inside a rich frame with a mirror, is set the portrait of Carlo Emanuele II, Duke of Savoy and husband of Maria Giovanna Battista of Savoy-Nemours, one of the few works preserved among the original furnishings of the first apartment created around 1690.

As you can see, Maria Giovanna Battista had a lavish taste: delicate porcelain found a place on the fireplace mantel, while the rest of the room was dotted with silver objects, including candle holders, vases, and braziers.
None of these objects are preserved today because, as in other cases, a few years after Madama Reale's death, they were taken to the mint to be melted down and recover the metal.
